job_title: Web Content Administrator in Chicago, IL
pros: - Very kind people - Good work enviornment
cons: -None that I want to share here

pros: As a student worker, it is a great way to learn skills and get experience in the IT field. Moody does not have an IT or CS degree, and this role is designed to give you all the experience needed to get a good-paying job in IT after graduating.
cons: You are essentially doing full-time level of work while being part-time. A lot is put on you, but compensation does not match the level of work that you do. You get paid the same as someone who just sits at a desk, while you are doing professional work that has major impacts throughout the entire Moody Bible Institute enterprise.

pros: Moody has a great legacy and location
cons: Chicago is an expensive place to live on this salary

review_title: The Heart is there but everything else...
pros: Christian community, and Hybrid WFH schedule
cons: Low pay and toxic expectations of its employees. Work/Life balance and boundaries are hard to maintain

pros: People are very kind and supportive

job_title: Community Service Officer in Chicago, IL

cons: You may not get the most preferable of work hours when you first start working as work hours are picked by seniority.

pros: You don't really do a whole lot.

pros: None that I can think of

pros: Christian work environment, excellent co-workers, managers who invest in their employees, getting to know them, their working style, communication style and even languages of appreciation. Training opportunities on-site galore. Free use of the gymnasium, coffee shop and affordable breakfast, lunch, and during the school year- dinner on site. Easy commute with public transportation (cta, Metra, etc). Moody goes out of their way to make employees feel appreciated and supported. It is near impossible to experience that elsewhere.
cons: Health insurance. Their health insurance will typically work out fine for most. My spouse and I unfortunately needed coverage that wasn't available through their plan.

review_title: Not What I Expected…But Totally Worth It
job_title: Donor Research Coordinator in Chicago, IL
pros: I love working at Moody Bible Institute! The people are generous. The leadership values your opinion. The benefits are superb! I wouldn’t want to work anywhere else.
cons: Since I am the only person who does research for Moody, there isn’t a lot of room for advancement.

review_title: Read all the required agreements and statements before accepting a position
pros: The staff are some of the most friendly and well meaning that I have worked with. I have become friends with so many of my peers and even several managers. On an individual level, this is an incredible place to work.
cons:
This company is not LGBTQIA+ inclusive. They are now requiring all staff to sign and agree to Moody's position on human sexuality.
The underlying current of homophobia is probably unnoticeable to the majority of the MBI community. Though I had known that the student body has been facing this for years, as a member of staff it hadn't been made obvious until recently.

pros: Great employees to work with, kindness in the offices, friendly atmosphere
cons: Low pay, often had to work more than 40 hours/week, not much diversity

review_title: Good for a starter job but get out once you have some experience.
pros: Wearing jeans to work is kind of nice.
cons: Environment with bad communication and hesitancy to move forward in any direction, particularly inclusion and innovation.

pros: I met some amazing people. Got good counseling experience.
cons: My supervisor seemed to not really want to supervise. Not very helpful.

review_title: Moody can be a good place to work, but there are many serious issues
pros:
Moody can be a great place to work early in your career because there is generally a very forgiving and flexible work environment, depending on your direct supervisor. I personally saw many hiring managers take a chance on a hire who ended up doing great work even though they may not have been the most qualified candidate on paper. This also means that there can be chances for quick advancement for those who do good work or are otherwise recognized somehow. I’ve seen many entry level hires gain a tremendous amount of work experience at Moody and move on to do great things at other organizations.

Moody also has a few genuinely wonderful people who work hard to make sure that the people on their teams are well cared for. These people do good work and are focused on achieving the goals of the organization. Working with or under one of these people can make working at Moody a great experience.
cons:
Moody is overall a very dysfunctional place. 

Salaries and benefits are far below market rates depending on your department and job function. Moody tends to hire desperate former students at extremely low salaries. 

There is widespread financial mismanagement (I was told to spend as much as I could on my corporate card because it got Moody extra cash back). At one point an employee bragged to me about how much money (approximately 40k) they spent on a piece of equipment which at the time of my departure from employment at Moody had been sitting, unused, for over 3 years. This employee also lectured me multiple times about “spending donor dollars wisely”.

Senior leadership (specifically institute president Mark Jobe) actively and repeatedly tells employees to leave if they aren’t willing to put their heads down and deal with the fact that working at a ministry requires more sacrifice (financial and time) than working at a normal organization. At the same time, they speak at great length about the financial successes the institute has experienced (this was said in multiple employee town hall meetings). There is a fundamental disconnect between upper management and individual contributors. My observation is that approximately 20% of the employees (particularly student and part time employees, who are not eligible for benefits) at Moody do around 80-90% of the work, while many full-time employees show up for a few hours each day, look busy, and simply leave without having done any real work.

Many employees lack basic social skills and appropriate workplace behavior. I’ve had to insist that colleagues stop touching me (after they couldn’t pick up on the fact that I was obviously uncomfortable with their touch, never mind that they shouldn’t have acted that way in the first place). Beyond this, many employees simply don’t exhibit ideal hygiene for an office environment, especially during a global pandemic. I’ve observed several colleagues clipping nails in shared spaces, refusing to wear masks even when required to by company, city, and state guidelines, and more. HR chooses not to engage in these conversations, asserting that it is up to individual managers to control this type of behavior. 

There is blatant favoritism shown in many departments. Certain employees have the ear of executives and manage to get what they want, even when it’s demonstrably bad for the organization or for other employees. This almost exclusively benefits older employees, especially those who are white and male. For example, I personally have seen countless younger employees, employees of color and female employees moved from offices to far less desirable cubicle spaces in favor of older, whiter, or male employees, even when the employees moved had far more reason to have an office

The annual review system is deeply flawed. Rather than having objective standards (or even standard training for managers), each manager is left to determine their own qualifiers for whether their direct reports have achieved their goals for the review period. This allows managers to treat their direct reports with as much or as little favoritism as they choose, leading to high scores for the direct reports they like and are friends with, and low scores for those they are not friends with. Coupled with aggressive evangelical superiority complexes, this is incredibly toxic for employees who have different opinions than their managers. 

Management frequently fails to listen to advice and input from qualified employees when that advice isn’t what they want to hear. At one point I implemented a new policy within the scope of my role and authority, only to have a counterpart of mine instruct their entire team to disregard said policy and continue doing what they’d always done. When I raised this to management above me, they ignored me and allowed my counterpart to continue in their ways.

My overall experience with Moody is that they are very comfortable skirting the line of questionably legal actions which are certainly unethical. For example, when I departed Moody, my manager failed to inform HR of my departure until after I’d left. As a result, my final paycheck was incorrect, and did not reflect the vacation payout I was owed. That paycheck arrived over two months late. Illinois law requires that final pay arrives no more than 1 pay period after departure. When I highlighted this fact, I was informed of my former manager’s failure to notify HR with no other excuse or explanation. Similarly, I’m aware of managers who have illegally shifted part time hours from one pay period to another to avoid paying overtime, and while the official HR policy prohibits this behavior, it is still rampant and to my knowledge, not addressed.

job_title: French Adjunct Professor in Chicago, IL
pros: I loved my students and coworker. Great school
cons: I did not have benefits and the pay was a bit low.

job_title: Web Content Specialist in Chicago, IL
pros: The Marketing department is moving forward and makes great strides each year. Great people to work with and very consistent.
cons: Progress is slow as the rest of Moody often feels stuck in its ways. There are also not a lot of ways to move forward or grow professionally in a career, it works because most people feel called to stay in the place but can be frustrating for some people.

pros: Moody has a strong mission and vision, which the employees and students are all participating in.
cons: After spending five years at Moody, I became cynical and skeptical. Leadership does not understand power dynamics and does not take constructive feedback in a meaningful way. Any criticism or short-coming is explained by being a 'mission-driven' workplace, at the cost of benefits, low salary, and poor employee experience.

job_title: Digital Marketing Manager in Chicago, IL
pros: Moody is a great place to go to school and get an education. It is also a great place as a student worker to get experience and prepare for the real world.
cons: Moody is one of the most toxic work environments I have ever seen or been a part of. I love Moody as I attended there for undergrad. I went right into working full time after graduation. I did get good experience, but I also saw a revolving door of super talented employees come and go because of management. I have never seen an organization more stuck in their ways and with less desire to make changes or improve. There is a stated desire to do so, but the actions prove otherwise. Time and time again I was ignored, overlooked, underappreciated, and lied to. As a Christian organization, I expected the employees to actually care about each other. However, there was more backstabbing, gossip, and sarcastic remarks than any for-profit workplace I have ever been in. For months, I engaged with management and upper level people to talk about and address the issues. I was told things were going to change and they were working on it. This never happened. My time at Moody culminated with me getting stabbed in the back once more, me losing my cool in a meeting (for the first time), and being told that I don't know what I am talking about because I am young and don't deserve respect. I was also required to work over holidays and vacation because of lack of communication and lack of respect. When I returned in the new year, I was let go without explanation. When asking for explanation, I was not given any and told by HR that they didn't really know. The only thing I do know was that I was very open with my supervisor about mental health struggles I was having and was told in my termination meeting that it was partially due to my mental health that I was let go. I would never recommend anyone who actually wants to enjoy their job work at Moody. The pay is low, respect is low, and change/innovation is non-existent.

pros: Pays well because of the Chicago minimum wage. Good working environment and good balance between school and work.
cons: There is not many bad things to say about this organization. Other than the steady decline of higher ups. HR needs to take into account how to discipline and further consider steps to letting go managers who do not do a good job of managing.

job_title: Senior Web Content Specialist in Chicago, IL
pros: Moody is an excellent organization with a solid mission. The organization and most of the employees are wholeheartedly invested in advancing the organization's mission, vision and values. Depending on the team you work for, there is a lot of value put into professional development and advancing in your discipline.
cons: As a nonprofit organization, Moody's salaries are not on par with the secular job market in Chicago. As a result, most employees cannot afford to live in the city comfortably unless they don't have families. Since Moody is an old organization with a long and rich heritage, there are times when the organization is slow to adopt change and there are some at the management level who are averse to and block progress because it doesn't fit their antiquated sensibilities.

review_title: Great people to work for in a great environment
job_title: Aviation Maintenance Instructor in Spokane, WA

job_title: Digital Marketing Specialist in Chicago, IL
pros: Opportunities for ownership of work, great community.
cons: Pay is on the low side.

pros: If you are on board with the mission, and work in an area that tries to be guided with it, this is an excellent place to work. There are attempts underway to change some of the negative aspects of the culture that have yielded great returns, and a sense that senior leadership is on task in trying to steer the rest of the organization toward those changes.
cons: Culture change is a long, hard process, especially in higher ed and perhaps most especially in a place as historic and driven by a degree of nostalgia as Moody. Change can take a long time, and some will embrace it enthusiastically while others (who may be lifers) may continue to resist, which can create political sorts of resistance. Some departments are innovating while others may stagnate; crossover is rare but improvements are happening in general. You will never work in a place like this because of the competitive salary or advancement opportunity, but because you serve the mission. If you or your area loses sight of that, then, it can be hard going, but otherwise it can be extremely rewarding.

pros: Good job for students needing money
cons: Extensive hours, long shifts and limited social life

job_title: Senior RPA Developer in Chicago, IL
pros:
Extremely nice working environment.
Serious Christian organization.
cons: Limited growing opportunities because of the size of the organization.

pros:
It's a good community of believers. There are exemplary workers and others that just float along, but you'll find that anywhere. 
In addition to being a job, it is a ministry. You can see your impact directly with the students on campus and with donors who give to support Moody.
cons:
As expected with a non-profit, the salary is not competitive. Thus you will see many employees stay for a few years and then leave for other jobs that can be more competitive.
Roles, promotions, salaries, etc are structured very hierarchical, which is becoming an antiquated business model. It often limits innovation and slows many business processes down.
The main campus is located in a very expensive-to-live downtown Chicago. Many employees cannot afford to live nearby and lengthy commutes can be the worst aspect of the job.

pros:
Company is pretty predictable and has all their rules and policies laid out. 
There is a specific culture to working here, which could be great if that fits with what you're looking for.   Most employees have been here for 15+ years, so they seem to be pretty happy.
cons: Primarily fundamentalist evangelical white employees from the city and surrounding suburbs.  HR takes forever to process any and all new hires.  Due to the organization being a non-profit, the budgets and perks are pretty minimum (no bonuses, ever).  The specific culture mentioned above might not be the most welcoming to those with different backgrounds/views.  There are a lot of different "silos" with each department, which creates a lot of running back and forth when working on an inter-departmental task.

pros: The atmosphere among workers is very much like a family in most departments. Most employees seem to truly enjoy working here and that comes threw in their attitudes and actions at work.
cons: Some of the systems in place are constantly changing. Normally change is good, but it seems that often at Moody, the management changes systems that do not need change swapping out a perfectly good system for a system that does not work well. This can be frustrating as one sees the things that do need to be changed, untouched while the things that work are swapped out for those that have problems.

review_title: The heavy lifting is accomplished through their 130+ years of good reputation.
pros: Good benefits. Resourced to accomplish the assigned tasks. Hard working colleagues. The world at your door steps. Caring, involved bosses.
cons: The commute may be necessary because the cost of living downtown is beyond reach. Red tape once in a while. Trust issues trying to be addressed. Not succeeding although the desire is great.

pros:
If you're conservative, evangelical, and don't take 1 Timothy 5:18 seriously, then you'll love Moody (provided your brand of conservative evangelicalism aligns with theirs).

I still have many good friends from Moody, though most of them are also former employees now.

In my professional experience, few non-profits offer 100% pay for short-time disability but Moody does.

The CEO during my employment, Dr. Paul Nyquist, instituted a number of new policies to improve trust between the employees and leadership including removing an employee ban on consuming alcohol or tobacco and gambling.
cons:
More than once, faculty members have attempted to expel students or terminate employees that did not fit their brand of conservative evangelicalism (sometimes successfully and including other faculty members).

To avoid paying overtime, some departments will ask employees to shift hours from one pay period to another.

When I worked there, morale was so low from frozen salaries to mass layoffs that the outside agency brought in to survey the employees said Moody had the lowest job satisfaction they had ever encountered.

pros:
1) Open displays of [Christian] faith are accepted and encouraged
2) Some of the students have wonderful work ethics and are very talented 
3) Some very wonderful people work here
cons:
1) Some men in the organization struggle with female leaders and authority figures - expect resistance if your are a woman that is more knowledgeable than your male counterparts
2) Some of the students feel entitled to privileges without doing any work or have an overall poor work ethic - you should screen potential student employees to avoid problems later

pros: Really good atmosphere among the staff and students on the university campus. I still have a lot of good connections with the people that I worked with there.
cons: The compensation was slightly behind the average for similar jobs in that area which could make it difficult to live near the university given it's downtown location. Quite a few of the employees have very long commutes because of this.

pros: Moody is a great place to work as far as the environment goes.  Positive and encouraging, and supportive of personal and professional growth.  In general, people are more pleasant to work with too.  Management (upper and lower) work hard to improve the areas that need change.
cons: Pay is well under the average for similar positions in my field (Technology).  Communication between departments is not very good.

pros:
- Christian environment. If you're VERY interested in working at an old-school non-profit Christian organization, you would probably be okay with working at Moody. 

- Family. It's not a bad place to work if you have a family, there are plenty of holidays, vacation compensation isn't terrible (10 business days to start, and you get more after 5, 10 and 20 years [or so] at the company) and flex hours are good. It's also friendly if you want to bring your wife and kids around on occasion. 

- Mentorship. Moody has some great people who work there. In my time there I was able to have several people I considered mentors who helped me develop as a professional and personally. 

- Gym. Moody has a nice gym, guys play basketball regularly over lunch. There's a decent weight room and cardio room, and a track for running. 

- Snacks. There's generally quite a few snacks around, not counting the cafeteria that employees can get food from for breakfast and lunch. 

- Accessibility. There's decent parking, and plenty of public transit close by. As an employee, if there's something you want to do downtown, it's really great to park at Moody and walk to most places.
cons:
Since this is the area that most people will read closely, I want to mention that I will try to be as objective as I can. Please understand that I without hesitation would say that I consider it an overall terrible place to work as a younger professional. 

- Dead end to careers. If you have any ideas of moving up the career ladder at Moody, you will be extremely disappointed. There have been people who have worked at Moody for 20, 30, even 40 years, so positions rarely open for advancement. To be honest, Moody isn't exactly growing either, so there aren't a ton of new positions from a growth perspective opening up. 

- Promotions/Advancement don't happen. In my time at Moody I saw this happen to multiple people in multiple roles: A position would open up, someone in the department who has worked there for xx years and knows the system applies for the job. They interview, go through the steps (usually, they are also handling the responsibilities of the position that opened up), and then they are passed over for someone from another department (happened 1+ times) or hire someone from outside the company (happened 3+ times).  In each case I can know of, the department suffered in some way. In two of the cases where someone was hired from outside the company, they were later let go for various reasons, mainly because they didn't fit the culture. 

- Management doesn't care. There was one situation particularly that I'm aware of where a department was struggling with a new hire just not getting along with their coworkers. Folks from that department went to HR on multiple occasions. When HR finally took action, someone asked "If in 3-6 months nothing changes and these concerns are still on going, what happens?" To which the response was "Nothing would happen, this should solve the issue." (Last I heard, every one of the employees in that department left the organization or moved to new departments eventually). Managers often handle stuff very secretly, and give no warning and ask for no input before making sweeping changes. Employees are expected to just go along with it, and anyone who questions it get reprimanded (in the most Christianese way)

- "Leadership" summit. While working at Moody, I had the opportunity to attend the global leadership summit. I absolutely loved the experience, and Moody had a large investment in it. However, I was also amazed how so many of the points of the leadership summit went completely in one ear and out the other of management. Statements like "If you move a manager into a high-performing department, and that department suddenly starts struggling, it's not the team's fault" seemed to fall on deaf ears.  I had a co-worker who on a regular basis would come back to the office and sit at their desk distraught with how poorly they were treated by our manager, often tearing up and had enough emotional stress it resulted in ultimately leaving Moody. 

- Fake Christianity. I do not mean that people there are not Christians, I mean it to mean that they are the move over-the-top Christians there are. The best explanation that I can think of is go look up Michael Jr's "Over Saved" video. While he means it as satire, there are entire departments at Moody I interacted with that were like that. While it might seem funny, it get's old really fast when you are struggling through something and someone looks you dead in the eye and says  "Sounds like you might just need to get right with the Lord, and confess your sin."

- Terrible pay. I want to break this down because this has more meaning behind it than just money. First off, Moody is based in downtown Chicago. The average price for a 1 bedroom apartment in downtown is something like $1600 a month. So it takes almost $20k/yr just to make rental payments. That doesn't count food, transportation, bills, or uncovered medial payments. For a young single man or woman, living on a >$40k per year salary is possible, as long as you don't have any major surprise payments, don't want to do anything except an occasional movie, try to date, and go on vacation anywhere but your parent's house. "Oh, but I could live in the suburbs." Yeah ok, if you want to spend at least 2-3 hours per day commuting. At one point during a celebration for someone who had worked at the company for ~30 years (whose spouse commuted with them and also worked downtown), was calculating how long they had commuted together in YEARS spent in the car.  

- Millennials? As a millennial myself, this was a direct impact. Moody is a revolving door for young talent.  There was no hope for a career, pay far below what peers made at other companies, and an inability to have any input or make any real difference in the company. There's also considerations like "maternity leave" that in my opinion should be a no-brainer for a Christian organization...but no, a young mother needs to use all vacation, personal time, and then go without pay for having a child. I could go on much longer about the issues that I faced, but I don't want to give more details. 

Overall, while some of the people are really amazing to get to know, the culture and way things are handled are not Christ-honoring. If you follow every rule, and are an uptight Christian, it's the perfect place for you. If you're an honest person who likes transparency, opportunities, and likes feeling valued, McDonalds (or anywhere else) would be a better starting point.

pros: The community of co-workers is often strong. This is a place where you are able to develop lasting friendships. In addition to this, Moody offers decent benefits for their full time employees as well. I received 401-3b package with Moody matching up to 3%, as well as a pension that was 4% of my salary. They have health, dental, vision, AD&D, and disability insurance.
cons:
Where to begin? Moody sets itself up as being a place that is devoted to spreading the truth of the gospel to as many people as possible. They do this through multiple ministries under the banner of "Moody Global Ministries." What this effectively means is that you are signing up to fulfill the ambiguous goal of spreading the truth of the gospel. This ends up being quite narrow to a singular interpretation of scripture that often looks a lot more aligned with a conservative political viewpoint. 

For example, Moody Radio constantly claims to be non-political, but constantly brings on guests that are anti net neutrality without any sort of second opinion from the other side of the aisle. Liberalism is a dirty word at Moody. Even if you have the Bible as your highest value, you have to keep any liberal views to yourself if you want to get ahead there. 

For example, When the refugee crisis was at a high level, I was told that talking about it would be too political, so Moody wouldn’t be taking an official position on the matter. This was not the first or the last time that Moody would avoid talking about what the Bible has to say about current event issues when the conclusions might affect the donor base. 

This is a major aspect of working at Moody. There is constant talking about doing this or that to keep donors happy. Moody Bible Institute is able to give every student a fully-paid tuition because of the generosity of these donors. This is also the case with Moody Radio, which gets roughly 80% of its funding from donations. Again, this isn’t a bad thing. That is how many non-profit or faith-based organizations work. Just understand that even though Moody talks about being only about the Bible, it is very limited to conservative interpretations of the Bible. 

Another area of concern is the impossible to work with management at all levels at Moody. It has been pretty public that Moody removed their president, provost, and CFO in one fell swoop. The board has also taken a stronger theological position on the inerrancy of Scripture, requiring all faculty to sign off on the Chicago Statement on Inerrancy. These actions have had a chilling effect on all levels of leadership. People are very afraid of having an opinion that would be deemed dangerous or too liberal. 

Senior leadership is obsessed with making Moody relevant again, but they are unwilling to listen to people who have actual ideas with how to go about that. They rest on their experience and position, and constantly demean anyone who is a lower position than they are. Everyone is fighting a war over their fiefdom—attempting to get as much power and control as they can, and it creates disfunction on many levels. It isn’t uncommon for a higher-level position to retire, or move to another department, and have the rest of the team take things in a “interim” capacity for five, six, seven (etc.) months. All the while feeling pressure from Senior leadership who make jokes about firing people because “I’m the boss.” 

Moody isn’t a bad place if you believe in what they are about. If it is an organization where you believe in their mission, there are real opportunities for you to work towards that end. But stray at all from their doctrine, and don’t be surprised when you get passed over for other yes-men. By the time I left my role there, I was beaten down, discouraged, and didn’t see any value in my work or myself. It is not an environment that cares for its employees.

pros: Moody has a wonderful mission and vision. The school, radio, and publisher serve their respective audiences well.
cons: Departments lack cohesive goals and strategy. In terms of work load, there is extreme position and department differentials. Some managers run their teams into the ground (working nights and weekends) and others are content to skim by (leaving early and working "remote" often).

pros: great location, friendly co-workers and staff. Its great to work with people who have a worldview based on ministry and the spread of the Gospel of Jesus Christ.
cons: opportunities for advancement are very hard to come by. I've applied to several full time positions and it seems preference is always given to new applicants, not employees who have  been working there for several years. Human Resources department is extremely slow in processing applications and correspondence about application process. Very frustrating to work with.

pros: Flexible schedule around class schedule, fun work environment, able to work with other students, a variety of skills will be used
cons: Many short shifts, at times the work can become monotonous, every third weekend is required to work, the work is not very challenging.

pros: A great Christian work environment. People are very nice and love helping others. I started working as a student and stayed for almost 4 years.
cons: Lack of communication between some departments.  Slow responses to issues and way to many meetings. A lot of talking and not a lot of action.

review_title: An incredible place to serve God
pros: Mission centric; authentic leadership -- they truly care about the mission of MBI, the students and the folks they are trying to serve.  They are good steward of the funds donated to fund student enrollment and operations.  It is a well run Christian organization.
cons: Depending on the role, there were minimal opportunities to advance because it is not a growing organization.

pros:
Salary fairly high compared to other nonprofits
Management very understanding
Any type of employee can advance - not just brown-nosers
cons:
Very traditional, hierarchical institution
Not much cooperation or coordination between departments
Decisions come down from on-high rather than involve those they effect

review_title: That was the place I understand the ownership of business
job_title: ETS Service Desk in Chicago, IL
pros:
1. God centered ministry focused 
2. People are nice to work with at least in the service desk. 
3. Good leadership that does not pose a top down approach as authoritative
cons:

pros: Very flexible hours. Worked in the kitchen and was afforded the opportunity to really gain experience and knowledge of the kitchen.

pros: Moody Aviation maintains high levels of excellence in all that they do, and encourages and enables that in their employees from day one.

job_title: Technical Support Manager in Chicago, IL

review_title: Best Boss Ever and Welcoming Environment

pros: The writing center is welcoming to all and it is a valuable resource. Meet all walks of life and share great experiences while writing.
cons: The writing center is pretty small and loud groups of people study in there.

review_title: Great people and some challenging dynamics

pros: Great people to work with. They care about your advancement and show it. My supervisor helped me find all the resources I need to advance my career.

pros: I was a great enviornment and people really enjoyed each other in the team!
